div1.p: DAUGHTER CARRIES ON FATHER'S WORK
MISS LAURA ARMISTEAD CARTER
(Drawing by Ernest Henderson, Jr., from a photograph by Underwood & Underwood)

GAL 1--DOLLY SUN MAG SEC--
SUNDAY NOV. 29--

p.hi:
Completes Data On
Yellow Fever To
Be Given Public

div1.p: BY DOLLY DALRYMPLE

MISS LAURA ARMISTEAD CAR-
TER, daughter of Dr. Henry
Rose Carter, Virginian, the man
who, isolated in a tiny quarantine
station of Ship Island, Gulf of Mex-
ico, experiencing with his young
wife and children the sordid hard
conditions of life, more of the sea
than the land, depending upon highly
irregular and infrequent communi-
cation with the mainland for sup-
plies and mail, originated the mod-
ern quarantine system and laid the
foundations of the work that was to
rid most of the world of the dread
scourge of yellow fever, is a visitor
to her brother, Dr. Henry Rose Car-
ter, III, and his gifted wife, Mel-
son Barfield Carter, for the Winter.

Miss Carter brings with her a
background of beauty and culture
her exquisite personality so refined
and so gracious, exemplifying the
distinguished ancestry which is hers,
and to which she is such an orna-
ment.

The author of several delightful
books, among them a volume of
poems, entitled “Wind and Blue
Water,” Miss Carter's most recent
efforts have been centered upon her
task of serving as historian for her
late father, Dr. Carter, assistant
surgeon general, U. S. Health Serv-
ice, in preparing his data on “Yel-
low Fever, An Epidemiological and
Historical Study of its place of
Origin” for publication in collabo-
ration with Dr. Wade Hampton
Frost, the book being just recently
off the press (1931).

THE task while a difficult one,
has been a labor of love with
this cultured young woman,
who was her father's constant com-
panion and “chum” during all her
childhood days, extending even unto
the time of his passing.

Dr. Carter's work was always
shared and appreciated by his fam-
ily, who followed him from one
place to another, during the experi-
mental stage he was engaged in, of
finding the cause and prevention of
yellow fever.

In charge of infected districts in
Mississippi and Louisiana, Dr. Car-
ter was able to note the progress
and infection of the disease from one
farm to another.

He made a record of his obser-
vations at this time, which was of
great value to Walter Reed, in the
latter's work on yellow fever and of
Dr. Carter's work, Walter Reed
said: “His work did more to im-
press me with the importance of an
intermediate host in yellow fever
than everything else that had been
done.”

In recognition of Dr. Carter's
training and his knowledge of yel-
low fever, he was asked to organize
a quarantine service in the Panama
Zone, in 1904. With Gen. Gorgas and
Walter Reed, he went down to “clean
up” the Isthmus, and the conditions
under which he first worked were
little short of primitive. There were
no lamps, and only a few candles,
one to every four sleeping rooms;
the food was wretched and there
was no water supply.

AND thereby hangs the tale of
yellow fever in Panama, for
Miss Carter tells interestingly
of how a dishpan outside the cook's
quarters nearly caused the death of
the entire personnel of a battleship
because it became a breeding place.

“I recall,” Miss Carter, continued,
“how I used to wait for my father
on the steps of the Yellow Fever
Hospital to the great dismay of the
Panamanians, who were sure that I
would soon become an ‘angel.’ What
they did not understand then, was
that the method was not to concen-
trate on the isolation of the patient,
from other persons, but to isolate
him from the mosquito, and to ex-
terminate these insects so they could
not become hosts to the yellow fever
organism, and thus spread the dis-
ease.”

It was this devoted daughter who
did the honors socially for her fa-
ther when her mother's ill health
prevented her from engaging in such
activities, and who assisted him in
the last great task of his colorful
life of service to mankind.

After years spent in Central and
South America, combating the dread
disease, the Rockefeller Foundation
asked him to write a history of yel-
low fever. He was known to be the
only man who could do it, both be-
cause of his experience, and because
his vast fund of information in-
cluded a knowledge of many lan-
guages, in which the first records of
disease were written. These com-
prised the Portuguese, Spanish, Ital-
ian, French, the Maya Mss., Mexican
hieroglyphics and the Latin written
by the priests during the early ex-
plorations in America.

IT WAS of this notable publica-
tion. “Yellow Fever an Epidemio-
logical and Historical Study of its
Places and Origin” that Miss Carter
and Dr. Frost prepared for publica-
tion after Dr. Carter's death, that
we talked to Miss Carter about the
other week when we had the pleas-
ure of meeting her and hearing of
her colorful life and achievements.

Said she: “On the day of his re-
turn from Peru (where, as sanitary
advisor of the Peruvian government,
he had just stamped out an epidemic
of yellow fever in the northern part
of that country). My father was
asked, by the Rockefeller Founda-
tion to write a history of yellow fe-
ver. His health was much broken
and he replied that he would almost
certainly die before the completion
of such a work. Realizing its impor-
tance, however, he added that if he
found he could plan the book in sec-
tions, ‘like a flight of steps,’ each
subdivision being complete in itself,
so that whoever came after him
could go on from where he left off,
he would undertake the word.

“He was able to so plan the book
and began work shortly thereafter
(early in 1922). After several severe
attacks of angina, the following Sum-
mer, he realized that he would have
even less time to give to the work
than he had anticipated. He there-
fore devoted all his efforts to finish-
ing during his lifetime a section
which should be complete in itself--
the early history of yellow fever.

“That is the book which now is pre-
sented to the public. Even this was
completed only by working through-
out long illnesses, the last year of
his life he was continuously confined
to his bed. Yet knowing that any of
the frequent interruptions to his
work might be the final one, in con-
stant discomfort, in almost constant
pain his energy and enthusiasm were
unabated and he worked on, dictating
towards the last (when too weak to
write) until within five hours of the
beginning of his last illness.

“And he had the final satisfaction
of knowing that his race against
time was won! By a narrow margin,
it is true, and with some legacies of
further work to others, before the
book, as he had planned it could be
given to the world. However, that
part of the work which no one but
he could have done, he did! It was
significant of the spirit in which the
book was written and of the appre-
ciation of the fact by others, that
when the news of his last illness
became known, out of the stream of
messages that poured in from his
confreres in all parts of the world,
all sent congratulations that he had
reached his goal! Not one man sent
a message of condolence!”

GAL 2--DOLLY SUN MAG SEC--
SUNDAY NOV. 29--

AN INTERPOLATION just here
suggests itself; that this emi-
nent physician so unselfish and
so devoted to his work, cared not to
live except his task be accomplished,
like the old Roman general who ex-
claimed:

“It is not necessary that I reach
Pelusium, it is not necessary that I
live!”

Taking up the conversation once
more Miss Carter said:

“At the time of my father's death
in 1925, the present book had been
fully drafted in its present scope and
content and the text completed
(though not revised), with the excep-
tion of the section on Africa. This
African section had been drafted
only roughly with numerous notes,
indicating additional references to be
consulted, etc.

“There remained then, after his
death, before sending the MSS, to
press:

list.item:
(a) Further research for the Afri-
can section.

(b) The verification of all refer-
ences, including those from contem-
porary records in Spanish, Portu-
guese, French, Italian, Latin, Dutch,
Maya, Nahuatl (Aztec), XV and
XVI Century English, etc.,

(c) The subsequent compilation of
the bibliography from these verified
references and, lastly.

div1.p:
It is due to the genius of Dr. Wade
Hampton Frost (a genius similar to
his own) that this final editing has
so closely followed the lines laid
down by my father.

“Turning to the completed book, as
here presented:

“As stated in the author's preface
(fortunately written by my father,
when he started work in 1922): “It
would seem natural, in writing a his-
tory of any disease’ to begin by col-
lecting accounts of its occurrence
and from them finally to deduce our
general principles (the so-called ‘epi-
demiology’ of the disease.) A differ-
ent--almost a reversed-order is fol-
lowed in the present book.

“This, because certain facts in the
epidemiology of yellow fever are es-
tablished and definitely known, while
the reports of its occurrence (and
non-occurrence) are frequently not
only unreliable, but erroneous. There-
fore ‘by writing the book back-
wards,’ as my father often phrased
it: That is, by beginning with a
statement of the conditions under
which, and only under which, yellow
fever can occur, the reader can, him-
self test the truth or error of the
historical evidence submitted later.”

AMONG the many beautiful en-
comiums which have been writ-
ten about Dr. Carter and his
work none is more significant than
the editorial by Douglas Freeman, in
The Richmond News, 1914, under the
heading, “Carter, Reed, Gorgas” upon
the occasion of the meeting of the
Southern Medical Association, there.

“The sentiment expressed in the
‘Editorial’ follows:

“Henry R. Carter, whose early work
made possible the experiments of
Walter Reed and the remarkable
sanitary conquests of Gorgas.

“The very mention of Reed com-
pletes the triumvirate. For while
young Gorgas was leading his cow
up Fifth Street and young Carter in
Hanover County was wondering at
war, the Gloucester County preacher's
boy was 14 years old, all unconscious
of his future fame, and scarcely
thinking of medicine as a career.

“We doubt if modern science re-
cords a like example of men of kin-
dred sympathy and almost common
birth whose labors in the same field
of endeavor yielded such notable re-
sults. Carter and Reed were native
Virginians, Gorgas, as the son of
Gen. Josiah Gorgas, passed the for-
mative years of his life in this state
and is knit to us by ties so
close that we always think of him as
a Virginian. They never knew one
another until manhood, but then they
cooperated with splendid comrade-
ship in the study of yellow fever--
that baffling scourge of the tropics.
Dr. Carter worked out the extrinsic
period of incubation, Dr. Reed at Co-
lumbia Barracks, Quemados, proved
the responsibility of the stegomyia
fasciata for the carriage of yellow
fever; Dr. Gorgas, first at Havana
and then at Panama, worked out
measures for the prevention of the
disease, without which, as all the
world knows, the greatest engineer-
ing feat of the ages, the completion
of the Panama Canal, could not have
been accomplished.

“The commonwealth that boasts
great soldiers like Washington, Jack-
son and Lee, great jurists like Wythe,
Marshall and Ròane and great states-
men like Jefferson, Madison and
Monroe rejoices that she has a claim
on three of the greatest benefactors
of our day--Carter, Reed and Gor-
gas.”

GAL 3 DOLLY Sun Mag SEC
SUNDAY, NOV 26--

ANOTHER is gleaned from “Notes
On Dr. Carter's Contributions
to Sanitary Science (unpub-
lished), by Wade Hampton Frost,
prepared at the request of the Rocke-
feller Foundation, on Dr. Carter's
book. “Yellow Fever; An Epidemio-
logical and Historical Study of Its
Place and Origin,” in which Dr. Frost
says:

“Finally, there is his history of
yellow fever, which more nearly than
any other work shows his full mas-
tery of the subject. It is character-
istic in its plan, in that he first lays
down, from modern knowledge, the
physical, biological and social condi-
tions which determine the character-
istic epidemiology of yellow fever.
Then, in the light of these condi-
tions, he reviews not the history of
yellow fever, but the history of the
period, from the earliest records of
Western Africa and America to 1648
when yellow fever emerges from ob-
scurity and becomes recognizable be-
yond question. In all that may throw
light on yellow fever, as in the old
Maya and Aztec records, in the de-
tails of losses in military expeditions
and colonies, in the analysis of social
conditions and commercial develop-
ment, in the study of early communi-
cation between Africa and America,
he has gone back to contemporary
records...and his interpretation of
the facts with reference to the light
which they throw on the presence or
absence of yellow fever is the most
delightful epidemiological analysis
that I have ever followed. Merely as
an historical research his history of
yellow fever would be a credit to an
historian. As a retrospective study in
epidemiology it is altogether unique
and, I believe, will be final as to the
principal questions which he dis-
cusses.”

LAURA CARTER was the first
girl on the Isthmus of Panama
when she went with her father
there; later came Margaret Gillick,
the lovely Mrs. Lloyd Noland, wife of
Birmingham's distinguished physi-
cian; and also Aileen Gorgas, the
daughter of the late Gen. Gorgas.

Dr. Carter had been to Cuba with
Gen. Gorgas previously, and was di-
rector of hospitals after the opening
of the quarantine station on the
isthmus. He acted for Gen. Gorgas
when things prevented the general
from doing so, and in all things stood
shoulder to shoulder with Gorgas in
all of his great work in Panama.

“The object was,” said Miss Carter,
in speaking of this period, “to clean
up Panama before the digging of the
canal; to clear out yellow fever and
control malaria.

“I might say that I was brought
up under the ‘yellow flag’ for my life
began with our residence on Chande-
leur Island and the Dry Tortugas in
the Gulf of Mexico.

“When we returned from Panama
in 1909, my father later was ordered
to Europe, on account of the cholera
epidemic (1912) to make regulations
which would protect the U. S. with as
little interference with commerce as
possible.”

Dr. Carter received many flatter-
ing offers from universities and col-
leges to become a member of their
faculty; but these he declined, and
Miss Carter, at this time became her
father's secretary and collaborator.

During the World War she was
“a dollar a year man,” Dr. Carter
being in charge of malarial control
of all training camps east of the
Rockies, and of the large industrial
plants making war materials.

For two years Miss Carter worked
during the war, and a year after the
war she worked with her father on
malarial control for the U. S. Public
Health Service. Later, in South
America, father and daughter worked
together under the Rockefeller Foun-
dation, and Dr. Carter remained in
Peru, as sanitary advisor to the
Peruvian government. Then the
Rockefeller Foundation asked him to
write his book on ‘yellow fever,’
which Miss Carter and Dr. Frost
prepared for publication.

During this period Dr. Carter and
his daughter also collaborated on
other interesting books, among them
“The Malaria Catechism,” taught in
schools throughout the malarial sec-
tion of the South, and its Spanish
translation in Latin America. It is
said to have the widest circulation
of any government publication.

Miss Carter's volume of poems,
“Wind and Blue Water,” is charm-
ing. It was inspired by travel in the
tropics where “the sparkle and space
and color and fresh winds” make the
soul “drunk with rapture.”

In this the volume is a group of
war poems touching upon events in
the World War. These were written
at a dinner party at which an of-
ficer, in speaking of women, said
that when in doubt of a beloved
woman's affection, a man should
knock boldly at her door (meta-
phorically speaking, of course), and
if no response was forthcoming, he
should leave at once and never re-
turn.

Miss Carter listened, and with her
knowledge of feminine psychology,
promptly wrote the charming poem
which ends with these prophetic
lines:

Fearful of so much joy
You turned away;
She cannot love if
She can thus delay;
And now you stand no more
Before my door--
Ah me--had you but knocked
A moment more.

MISS CARTER'S mother was the
famous beauty, Laura Eugenia
van Hook, herself a talented
writer, and many eminent critics pre-
dicted a brilliant literary career for
her; but, “under the yellow flag”
her enchanting stories turned into
more practical and domestic things
and the world was deprived of her
talents in that direction.

In her youthful days she conducted
a column on the same newspaper
with Eugene Field, and her gifts as
a musician, linguist, and writer, at-
tracted the attention of many dis-
tinguished people.

In conclusion, Dr. Carter's book
on yellow fever, which his daughter
and Dr. Frost have so accurately
prepared for publication, has at-
tracted, among many others, the
League of Nations, which has a com-
mittee on quarantine regulations for
travel. It is felt that the book will
be of great help to the league and to
all others in authority, in reaching
sound conclusions with reference to
rules, regulations and laws concern-
ing this dread disease.
